Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Transforming Construction by Digital Fabrication of Concrete with Carbonate Cement
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project seeks to advance concrete construction technology by reinventing cement production with carbonate-based, near CO2-neutral cement and concrete surrogates. It is proposed to utilize flue-gas borne CO2 as an 'ingredient' to rapidly mineralize digitally fabricated construction components. The reinvented cementation chemistry and process enable producing high-quality building elements faster than it is possible today. It also enables the integration of a confluence of technologies, mating carbonate-based cementation solutions with digital fabrication technologies to overcome challenges facing the construction sector today, including its large CO2 footprint, while also potentially improving productivity. By rationalizing workflows, enhancing automation, and originating new materials, this project develops innovative pathways to disruptively transform the construction sector.

This I-Corps project exploits new advances made the rapid ambient temperature mineralization of carbonate solids. The central technology is based on approaches for sequestering CO2 borne in flue gases in light metal carbonates. This renders carbonate-based cementation agents, which offer performance that is equivalent or superior to traditional cement and concrete. Recent studies have revealed that carbonation hardening process is rapid. Under suitable conditions it proceeds to completion in 24 hours or less, substantially faster than existing cementation solutions. Due to their simple composition and chemical homogeneity, the carbonate cement precursors offer flexible, and well-controllable rheology, an important prerequisite for enabling digital fabrication using these materials. Taken together, carbonate-cements offer new routes towards CO2-neutral cementation, and construction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Carbon Upcycling team participated in the NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) cohort in Atlanta in the Spring of 2017. The team consisted of Gabriel Falzone (Entrepreneurial Lead, EL), Bu Wang (Principal Investigator, PI), and Claudio Manissero (Industrial Mentor, IM). Through the I-Corps program, the team aimed to evaluate the product-market fit of the team’s Carbon Upcycling technology. The technology utilizes industrial waste streams, e.g., flue gas and coal fly ash from power plants, to fabricate a novel construction material designed to replace concrete. Compared to the traditional concrete, the new material can achieve equivalent performance with similar low-cost materials inputs, but has a lower carbon footprint, while offering improved quality control, and enhanced suitability for advanced digital fabrication processes.

 

During the I-Corps program, the team received intensive training covering various aspects of the technology commercialization process, including fundamental strategy and process, business model canvas development, customer discovery, etc. The team conducted 103 interviews with industrial professionals across the United States. The interviewees are from various sectors in the construction ecosystem, including architectural design, engineering and construction, chemical manufacturers, electricity generation, etc. From these interviews, the team gathered unbiased information on the pain points faced by potential customers, which was used to evaluate each hypothesized portion of the business model canvas (e.g., value propositions, customer segments) to aid in the potential commercialization of the team’s technology.

 

By analyzing the information obtained from the interviews, the team made critical pivots on the value propositions and established several preliminary customer segments, e.g., construction clients seeking advanced sustainability certificates, technology managers at construction chemicals manufacturers, and managers at coal-fired power plants. In addition, the team also gained valuable insights into the ecosystem of the construction industry, and identified future research strategies to develop new value propositions. Although a “no go” decision was made at the closing of the I-Corps cohort due to the need for additional market research at the time, the preliminary business model canvas developed during the program has served as the basis for the team to continue the business development/customer discovery efforts thereafter. Such ongoing efforts are focused towards understanding the needs of concrete masonry producers and making further connections in the cleantech innovation sector. After further refining the value propositions and contacts with potential investors, the EL is now leading the effort to establish a startup. 

 

Furthermore, learnings from the I-Corps program have fundamentally impacted the technology development and commercialization efforts in the team. Customers and the product-market fit have become the most emphasized issues in developing and evaluating innovative technologies. The team expects to adopt similar methodologies in future commercialization efforts, with strong focus on non-biased market research and rigorous business model canvas development. 

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2018
Modified by: Bu Wang
